Turne, gentle straunger!  turne awhyle!</br>And list unto my plainte,</br>I loste my harte to a damzell fayre,</br>Whome I fancy'd was a saynte.
I thoughte her mynde was lyke her face,</br>In perfect beautie drest;</br>I thoughte her harte was framed sincere,</br>And spotlesse as her breste.
Her eie was lyke the morninge starr,</br>And lyke the rose her cheeke,</br>Her smyle was gaye as summer skies,</br>Her manner chaste and meeke.
Oft by the margent of the brook</br>That neare her dwellinge flow'd,</br>I used to meete the peerless mayde,</br>For whome my busome glow'd.
When with a coronal of flowers</br>I deck'd her heben haire,</br>Proud as the pavone of its plumes,</br>Wou'd Brassolis appeere.
But dire commotions shooke the lande,</br>And marr'd the hopes of love;</br>A soldier bred, I led my bande</br>The toils of warr to prove.
"Retire, my Brassolis!"  I cry'd,</br>"Avoyde the warfull playne,</br>And in a convent safe abide,</br>Till peace shall smyle agayne."
The artfull fayre appeer'd to grieve,</br>And slowlie to departe;</br>Her persaunt eie I dar'd beleeve</br>The herald of her harte.
The red-cross banner soone prevayl'd,</br>The crescent proudlie shone,</br>Victorious shouts our ears regal'd,</br>And valourous deeds were done.
The battle o'er, I chaunc'd to see</br>A palmer on the fielde,</br>Whose whole attention seem'd to be</br>Fix'd on my silver shielde.
He wore a garberdine of gray,</br>With cockle shells enlay'd,</br>Red sandals were upon his feet,</br>A bonnet on his head.
I parley'd with this palmer gray,</br>And a letter to hym gave,</br>I pray'd hym seeke my bonny bride,</br>And meete me at the cave.
And thus I wrote, "Our conquering bande</br>Are with fresh laurels crown'd,</br>And in the archives of the lande</br>Their deeds will be renown'd.
"But tho' a soldier's cares detaine</br>Thy faithful lover here,</br>The hours are yeeres till I agayne</br>See Brassolis appeere.
"No signs of warr will paine thy sighte,</br>The sword is caste asyde,</br>And victory, in laurels dight,</br>Woos my betrothed bryde.
"Farewell to bassonet and speare,</br>To hauberk, launce, and glaive:</br>The olive tree is planted here,</br>And waves o'er yonder cave.
"Come then, my love!  and join me here;</br>A palfrey I provyde,</br>A pilgrim will this message beare,</br>Who swears to be thy guide."
I sent this letter to the mayde,</br>And told the pilgrim gray</br>His service largely shou'd be paid,</br>Then bade hym haste away.
The palmer these credentials tooke,</br>My benison I gave—</br>I trusted to hys honest looke,</br>And to hys habit grave.
But the false mayde for whome I sigh'd</br>Was fashion'd to betraye,</br>She, tho' affianced for my bryde,</br>Fled with the palmer gray.
Ungrateful Brassolis!  I mourne</br>My own credulity,</br>And in my busome beare a wounde</br>That knows no remedie.
Ensample sad to all mankinde</br>My riven harte may prove,</br>And teache them to escape the pangs</br>Of ill-requited love.</br>
